snippet: Mr. Ghani’s inauguration on Monday came under a cloud after a power-sharing agreement with the runner-up, Abdullah Abdullah, nearly collapsed.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Ghani’s inauguration on Monday came under a cloud after a power-sharing agreement with the runner-up, Abdullah Abdullah, nearly collapsed.
abstract: Ashraf Ghani is inaugurated as president of Afghanistan, punctuating season of grave political crisis with peaceful transition of power that stands as rarity in country marked by four decades of war; Ghani appoints Abdullah Abdullah, his rival in contested runoff election, as government's chief executive officer and shares inaugural stage with him.

headline.main: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan Is Sworn In, Even as He Shares the Stage
headline.print_headline: President Is Sworn In, and Shares the Stage

byline.original: By ROD NORDLAND and DECLAN WALSH

snippet: By failing to order a fair trial for five men convicted of rape, the new president sent a signal that a corrupt judicial system is good enough.
lead_paragraph: By failing to order a fair trial for five men convicted of rape, the new president sent a signal that a corrupt judicial system is good enough.
abstract: Editorial contends trial of five Afghan men convicted of gang rape, and subsequent hangings, was first vexing test for new Pres Ashraf Ghani, and he failed; maintains by refusing to stay execution and to demand fair trial, Ghani signaled that country's arbitrary and corrupt judicial system is good enough.

headline.main: Grim Executions in Afghanistan

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

snippet: In August, a group of men stopped a family’s car and assaulted four women; the men convicted of the attack said their confessions were obtained through torture.
lead_paragraph: In August, a group of men stopped a family’s car and assaulted four women; the men convicted of the attack said their confessions were obtained through torture.
abstract: Afghanistan hangs five men accused of gang rape despite strong protests from United Nations human rights official, who had called on Pres Ashraf Ghani to stay the executions because of concerns about an unfair trial; Ghani inherited execution order from his predecessor Hamid Karzai, who signed it on the day before he left office.

headline.main: 5 Afghan Men Hanged in Rape Case Despite Concerns About Their Trial
headline.print_headline: 5 Afghan Men Hanged in Rape Case Despite Concerns About Their Trial

snippet: After months of tension over elections in Afghanistan, a look at the recent history of presidential power in the country that led to the long fight this time around.
lead_paragraph: After months of tension over elections in Afghanistan, a look at the recent history of presidential power in the country that led to the long fight this time around.

headline.main: Inside the Afghan Quest for Power

snippet: If the country is to survive in one piece, its new leaders must act fast to correct the failures of the last decade.
lead_paragraph: If the country is to survive in one piece, its new leaders must act fast to correct the failures of the last decade.
abstract: Op-Ed article by author Ahmed Rashid contends power-sharing agreement between Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah, leading candidates in Afghanistan's presidential election, is makeshift compromise that only reveals shortcomings of United States' 13-year presence; warns country could relapse into civil war; urges Ghani and Abdullah to call for gathering of tribal and elected representatives as soon as possible to address failures of last decade.

headline.main: Afghanistan’s Failed Transformation

snippet: The agreement, long delayed, allows 9,800 American and about 2,000 NATO troops to remain in Afghanistan after the international combat mission formally ends on Dec. 31.
lead_paragraph: The agreement, long delayed, allows 9,800 American and about 2,000 NATO troops to remain in Afghanistan after the international combat mission formally ends on Dec. 31.
abstract: American and Afghan officials sign long-term security pact nearly one year after agreement was cast into limbo by breakdown of trust between the two nations; deal will allow 9,800 American and about 2,000 NATO troops to remain in Afghanistan after the international combat mission ends in December.

headline.main: Mending Alliance, U.S. and Afghanistan Sign Long-Term Security Agreement
headline.print_headline: Mending Alliance, U.S. and Afghanistan Sign Long-Term Security Agreement

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

byline.contributor: Julie Hirschfeld Davis contributed reporting from Washington.
byline.original: By DECLAN WALSH and AZAM AHMED

snippet: Abdullah Abdullah threatened to pull out of the inauguration Monday after his camp said it felt that the declared winner, Ashraf Ghani, violated an agreement not to publicly reveal the vote totals.
lead_paragraph: Abdullah Abdullah threatened to pull out of the inauguration Monday after his camp said it felt that the declared winner, Ashraf Ghani, violated an agreement not to publicly reveal the vote totals.

headline.main: Runner-Up in Afghan Elections Threatens to Boycott Inauguration

snippet: Speaking to his cabinet and senior staff members, the departing Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, said the United States “did not want peace for Afghanistan.”
lead_paragraph: Speaking to his cabinet and senior staff members, the departing Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, said the United States “did not want peace for Afghanistan.”
abstract: Outgoing Afghan Pres Hamid Karzai denounces the United States during farewell speech, arguing that country betrayed the cause of peace in Afghanistan; offers advice to Ashraf Ghani, who will replace him.

headline.main: In Farewell Speech, Karzai Calls American Mission in Afghanistan a Betrayal
headline.print_headline: In Farewell Speech, Karzai Calls American Mission in Afghanistan a Betrayal

byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg contributed reporting from Washington.

snippet: After eight months of enmity over the protracted presidential election, Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah will have to confront the challenges of jointly governing their country.
lead_paragraph: After eight months of enmity over the protracted presidential election, Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah will have to confront the challenges of jointly governing their country.
abstract: Ashraf Ghani is declared victor in Afghanistan's disputed presidential election, and will join opponent Abdullah Abdullah to form national unity government; decision follows eight months of enmity over election results; two men will face significant challenges in jointly governing a country that in many ways is far worse off than it was before the campaign began.

headline.main: After Rancor, Afghans Agree to Share Power
headline.print_headline: After Rancor, Afghans Agree to Share Power

byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg contributed reporting from Washington.

snippet: In negotiations over the disputed presidential election, Abdullah Abdullah, who is widely expected to lose, has insisted that the count not be made public.
lead_paragraph: In negotiations over the disputed presidential election, Abdullah Abdullah, who is widely expected to lose, has insisted that the count not be made public.
abstract: Afghan presidential rivals Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani agree on power-sharing deal after five tumultuous months; under deal, Ghani will hold post of president, with significant power granted to Abdullah.

headline.main: Afghan Presidential Rivals Finally Agree on Power-Sharing Deal
headline.print_headline: Afghan Presidential Rivals Finally Agree on Power-Sharing Deal

snippet: The Department of Defense has identified 2,333 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,333 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
abstract: Defense Department confirms death of American service member in Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: In a speech, Abdullah Abdullah congratulated the president-elect, Ashraf Ghani, and confirmed that he would accept a senior position in the government.
abstract: Abdullah Abdullah, runner-up in Afghanistan's bitterly disputed presidential election, congratulates president-elect Ashraf Ghani and confirms that he will join government.

headline.print_headline: Afghan Runner-Up, in Tone of Compromise, Confirms He Will Join Government

lead_paragraph: Five of the seven defendants in a gang rape case were condemned to death, despite their claims that their confessions were extracted through torture.
abstract: Afghan appeals court confirms death sentences against five of seven defendants in notorious robbery and rape case, despite their claims that their confessions were extracted through torture.

snippet: Western officials observing the election pressed for the final numbers to be withheld, as demanded by the losing candidate before he joined a unity government, multiple sources said.
lead_paragraph: Western officials observing the election pressed for the final numbers to be withheld, as demanded by the losing candidate before he joined a unity government, multiple sources said.
abstract: Decision by Afghan officials to announce new president without releasing final vote counts comes as result of pressure from senior Western officials; omissions of results was requirement by Abdullah Abdullah before he joined national unity government with declared winner Ashraf Ghani.

headline.main: Monitors of Afghan Vote Are Said to Back Secrecy
headline.print_headline: Monitors of Afghan Vote Are Said to Back Secrecy

byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg contributed reporting from Washington, and Jawad Sukhanyar from Kabul.

snippet: A brokered solution to the electoral dispute was far from democratic but sets the stage for a milestone: a peaceful transfer of power.
lead_paragraph: A brokered solution to the electoral dispute was far from democratic but sets the stage for a milestone: a peaceful transfer of power.
abstract: Editorial addresses Ashraf Ghani's victory in Afghanistan's disputed presidential election, and nascent political agreement with opponent Abdullah Abdullah; argues that while elections were marred by fraud, decision nonetheless marks a tenuous milestone that may give government a chance to contain the Taliban and begin mending a nation scarred by decades of war.

headline.main: A Shaky Step Forward in Afghanistan
headline.print_headline: A Shaky Step Forward in Afghanistan

snippet: Ashraf Ghani was declared the winner of the presidential elections after he and Abdullah Abdullah signed a deal on Sunday for a power-sharing government in Kabul.
lead_paragraph: Ashraf Ghani was declared the winner of the presidential elections after he and Abdullah Abdullah signed a deal on Sunday for a power-sharing government in Kabul.

headline.main: Afghanistan Gets a New President
